1.title: Episode #4.1
1.plot: This series kicks off with interviews with social commentator Hugh Mackay, New York Times bestselling author Libba Bray and American political philosopher and professor at Harvard University Michael J. Sandel.

2.title: Episode #4.2
2.plot: We meet English author and broadcaster Kate Mosse, and Canadian born Jewish-Australian columnist and author Danny Katz.

3.title: Episode #4.3
3.plot: We talk to William Dalrymple, award winning British historian and writer; and spoken word artist Kate Tempest. We also find time to meet Sylvia Nasar, the author of "A Beautiful Mind", which inspired the academy award-winning movie.

4.title: Episode #4.4
4.plot: In this week's interview we meet leading feminist author Anne Summers to talk about her latest book release. Also, Australian musician Archie Roach lets us know what he is up to.

5.title: Episode #4.5
5.plot: This week we talk to Robert Greene, American author and speaker known for his books on strategy, power and seduction. We also meet two first time novelists, Hannah Richell & Dawn Barker.

6.title: Episode #4.6
6.plot: Peter John Cantrill talks about "Public Sydney: Drawing the City" that he co-wrote with university friend Philip Thalis. Eli Horowitz shows us his new book app and we take a sneak peak into Lauren Beukes latest literary offering, "The Shining Girls".

7.title: Episode #4.7
7.plot: In this week's episode, Shelf Life talks to American author Cheryl Strayed about being on Oprah's book club, Philosopher Damon Young discusses "Philosophy in the Garden", and San Francisco based rock journalist Sylvie Simmons chats about her amazing career.

8.title: Episode #4.8
8.plot: This week we talk to Edward Rutherfurd about his latest novel "Paris". We also talk to award winning children's author Judith Ridge, as well as Spanish novelist Carlos Ruiz Zafón.

9.title: Episode #4.9
9.plot: In this week's episode American novelist Claire Messud, and local writers Courtney Collins and James Roy.

10.title: Episode #4.10
10.plot: We meet William McInnes, Australian actor and writer. We speak to Anne Barbara Deveson AO about her career as an author and Brian Falkner about children's literature.

11.title: Episode #4.11
11.plot: In our final author interviews from the series, we join poetry slam champion Anis Mojgani, meet Hannah Kent and talk about her debut novel, as well as chatting to author Nick Earls and illustrator Terry Whidborne about their trilogy "Word Hunters".

1.title: Episode #1.1
1.plot: In this first episode of Shelf Life, we meet author Anita Heiss and take a tour of the historic Mitchell Wing of the NSW State Library. In our Bookmark segment, we review Anita's book "Manhattan Dreaming" and Max Cryer's "Who Said That First?".

2.title: Episode #1.2
2.plot: This week we talk to Ashley Ekins and take a trip to Lidcombe Library. We review "1918: Year of Victory", edited by Ashley Ekins, and Richard Flanagan's "Wanting".

3.title: Episode #1.3
3.plot: In this episode, we meet author Maggie Joel, and we find what Penguin Plays Rough is all about. We review Maggie's book "The Second-Last Woman in England" and "Leave To Remain: A Memoir" by Abbas El-Zein.

4.title: Episode #1.4
4.plot: This week we talk to Hugh Mackay, author and social researcher. We visit Kirribilli Bookshop, and find out what's happening at Parramatta Library. In our Bookmark segment, we review "Love and Other U-Turns" by Louisa Deasey, and Nick Cave's "The Death of Bunny Munro".

5.title: Episode #1.5
5.plot: In Shelf Life this week, we talk to author/illustrator Brownwyn Bancroft and we meet the finalists of the 2010 "What Matters?" writing competition held at the Whitlam Institute at the University of Western Sydney. We review "The Little Prince" by Antoine de Saint-Exupery, and "Jasper and Abby and the Great Australia Day Kerfuffle" by Kevin Rudd and Rhys Muldoon.

6.title: Episode #1.6
6.plot: We talk to Jane Goodall, who takes a refreshingly down-to-earth look at the modern novel. We travel to Megalong Books in Leura, and we meet the founder of the Footpath Library, an amazing institution that provides books to people who are homeless. We review "Making News" by Tony Wilson, and "How to Cause a Scandal" by Laura Kipnis.

7.title: Episode #1.7
7.plot: This week, we visit Merrylands Library and take you on a writing retreat at Varuna House. We review Miranda Darling's "The Troika Dolls" and "The Happiest Refugee" by Anh Do.

8.title: Episode #1.8
8.plot: We meet author Greg Noble, whose research into multicultural identity led to the book "Lines in the Sand", about the Cronulla riots. We take a trip to Auburn Library to meet living, breathing books. We review two intriguing publications: Nikki Greenberg's graphic novel version of Shakespeare's "Hamlet" and Bob Dylan's "Forever Young", illustrated by Paul Rogers.

9.title: Episode #1.9
9.plot: This week we visit Springwood Library, and we talk to author and historian Carol Liston about her pictorial history book "Liverpool and District". We review DBD Pierre's "Lights Out in Wonderland" and "Room" by Emma Donoghue.

10.title: Episode #1.10
10.plot: This week, we visit the Whitlam Collection at the University of Western Sydney; and talk to the founder of an independent publishing house, ACE Press. We review Stephen King's "Under The Dome" and "The World Beneath" by Cate Kennedy.

11.title: Episode #1.11
11.plot: Shelf Life spent some time at the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival. This week we talk to author Steven Lang about his book "88 Lines About 44 Women".

12.title: Episode #1.12
12.plot: We meet the author of "Baba Yaga Laid an Egg", Dubravka Ugresic, at the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival.

13.title: Episode #1.13
13.plot: We talk to author and journalist Jack Marx about his book "Australian Tragic: Gripping tales from the dark side of our history".

14.title: Episode #1.14
14.plot: In this week's interview from the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet author Patrick Cullen, who takes us through the process of writing his first novel, "What Came Between".

15.title: Episode #1.15
15.plot: This week at the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, we talk to author and magazine columnist Mark Dapin about his debut novel "King of the Cross", winner of the 2010 Ned Kelly Award. We also take you to the 2010 Zine Fair, held at the Museum of Contemporary Art at the The Rocks.

16.title: Episode #1.16
16.plot: We meet spoken word artist Emilie Zoey Baker at the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, and get a taste of performance poetry.

17.title: Episode #1.17
17.plot: In this week's feature episode from the 2010 Sydney Writers'Festival, Shelf Life talks to Australian author Frank Moorhouse about writing, mentoring and the value of the book.

18.title: Episode #1.18
18.plot: We talk to Clinton Caward, who's worked in a number of different industries before settling down to write his first novel "Love Machine".

19.title: Episode #1.19
19.plot: In this week's episode from the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet Fiona McGregor, who talks about the genesis of her fourth novel "Indelible Ink".

20.title: Episode #1.20
20.plot: In our final episode from the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, we join the Westside Writers' Group to see and hear their latest works-in-progress. Ivor Indyk from the University of Western Sydney is the facilitator of the group, and he gives us an insight into how the group has developed.

1.title: Episode #2.1
1.plot: In this first episode of the second series, we meet screenwriter Anny Slater, talk about the future of books with the owner of Macleay Bookshop and spend an evening at a spoken word event. In our Bookmark segment, we review "Lover's Dictionary" by David Levithan and Patti Smith's self titled book "Patti Smith".

2.title: Episode #2.2
2.plot: This week we talk to playwright and actor Brendan Cowell, and take a trip to Marrickville Library. We also found time to have a chat with Ivor Indyk and Fiona Wright who run Giramondo Press, a publishing house with a mission. We review "This Is Shyness", by Leanne Hall; and Sarah Winman's "When God Was A Rabbit".

3.title: Episode #2.3
3.plot: In this episode we meet writer Stephanie Dowrick and we delve into the underground world of Science Fiction and Fantasy. We also visit a Chinese Calligraphy exhibition with a twist. We review Tim Pegler's book "Five Parts Dead" and "The Sound of a Wild Snail Eating" by Elisabeth Tova Bailey.

4.title: Episode #2.4
4.plot: This week we talk to not one but two renowned authors. We have the pleasure of meeting Australian author Bernard Cohen, and the creator of the "Dexter" dynasty, Jeff Lindsay. We visit one of the Berkelouw bookshops in Leichhardt and discover their rich history. In our Bookmark segment, we review "Blue Skies" by Helen Hodgeman and Suzanne Ruta's "To Algeria, With Love".

5.title: Episode #2.5
5.plot: In Shelf Life this week, we talk to author Jesse Blackadder about her newest novel and we meet the dedicated staff at Vision Australia. Daniel Akst speaks with us about the growing industry of self help books, and why they are necessary. We review "Between Borders And Buses" by Darren Assey and "Girl Saves Boy" by Steph Bowe.

6.title: Episode #2.6
6.plot: We talk to writer and critic James Bradley about the difficulties behind judging other authors' work, and meet poet Joanne Burns who has a new collection out this year. We travel to Sydney for the Mardi Gras Short Story LGBTQ Competition and find out why this type of event is so important. We review "Fall Girl" by Toni Jordan and "August" by Bernard Beckett

7.title: Episode #2.7
7.plot: This week, we visit the "Behind The Lines" Exhibition, a display of this year's best political cartoons brought to you by the Whitlam Institute and Riverside Theatre. Then we take you on a trip down the coast to enjoy the Lifeline South Coast Big Book Fair and see what literary gems they discover this year. We also bring you along to the launch party of the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival to see who and what they have in stall for us this year. We only review one book this week, Tea Obreht's sensational first novel "The Tiger's Wife".

8.title: Episode #2.8
8.plot: We meet first time soldier/author and testicular cancer survivor Matthew Carr whose novel "Battle Scars" documents his emotional journey. We take a trip to a Digital Stories Launch at the International Cultural Exchange in Parramatta, and speak to well known food critic John Newton. We review Christina Hopkinson's "The Pile of Stuff at the Bottom of the Stairs" and Leslie Cannold's "The Book of Rachael".

9.title: Episode #2.9
9.plot: This week we visit the tech savvy library in Castlehill, and talk to Ebook author Patrick Flanigan about the pros and cons of self publishing online. Then we are lucky enough to interview Dr Barry Jones about the government's plans for the future of the Australian publishing industry. We review Stephen Orr's "The Cruel City" and "The Summer Without Men" by Siri Hustvedt.

10.title: Episode #2.10
10.plot: This week we visit the Norman Lindsay Festival of Children's Literature in the Blue Mountains and talk to Norman's granddaughter. We speak with Larry Writer about the topic of his latest book, the infamous Bumper Farrell and visit revered author Kathryn Heyman and discuss her role teaching in the Faber Academy. We review 2 children's books this week, Maryanne Harrison's "T.E.D.'s First Day at School" and "Press Here" by Herve Tullet.

11.title: Episode #2.11
11.plot: Last years Sydney Writers' Festival was such a success that Shelf Life decided to spend some time at the 2011 festival. This week we talk to author Kate Holden about her book "The Romantic: Italian Nights & Days".

12.title: Episode #2.12
12.plot: We meet Elisabeth Wynhausen, the author of "Dirt Cheap: Life at the Wrong End of the Job Market", at the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival.

13.title: Episode #2.13
13.plot: We talk to Spoken Word Artist Miles Merrill about the origins, process and growing popularity of this relatively new art form.

14.title: Episode #2.14
14.plot: In this week's interview from the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet journalists Timothy Dick and Cath Keenan, who took some time to tell us about their great new children's writing centre, "The Sydney Story Factory".

15.title: Episode #2.15
15.plot: This week at the 2010 Sydney Writers' Festival, we talk to speechwriter Lucinda Holdforth. She is also the author of two nonfiction works, :True Pleasures: A Memoir of Women in Paris" and "Why Manners Matter: The Case for Civilised Behaviour in a Barbarous World".

16.title: Episode #2.16
16.plot: We meet Neill James, the Director of the Plain English Foundation. He enlightens us about some common misconceptions when it comes to language.

17.title: Episode #2.17
17.plot: In this week's feature episode from the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival, Shelf Life talks to American author Tea Obreht about her astonishing debut novel, "The Tiger's Wife".

18.title: Episode #2.18
18.plot: We talk to Jennifer Mills, whose new book "Gone" is a beautiful way to travel across Australia. She speaks about the good and the bad of being a rural writer.

19.title: Episode #2.19
19.plot: In this week's episode from the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet novelist and writing teacher Sue Woolfe,

20.title: Episode #2.20
20.plot: We meet John M. Green, a lawyer turned thriller author who has established a new type of publishing model.

21.title: Episode #2.21
21.plot: This week Shelf Life meets Ursula Dubosarsky. She wanted to be a writer from the age of six and has now well and truly fulfilled that ambition. She has now published over 30 books for children and young adults

22.title: Episode #2.22
22.plot: In our final author interview from the 2011 Sydney Writers' Festival, we join Favel Parrett in conversation about life as a writer and her new book "Past The Shallows".

23.title: Episode #2.23
23.plot: This week we kick off our coverage from the Sydney Writers' Festival Suburban Events. Broadcaster, journalist and author Mike Carlton gives a fascinating talk about his new book "Cruiser" at Hornsby Library.

24.title: Episode #2.24
24.plot: Libbi Gorr is an author alongside the many other talents she possesses. We join her for a fun filled author talk at the North Ryde Community Hall.

25.title: Episode #2.25
25.plot: Shelf Life veteran Hugh McKay graces us with his charming presence once again. Hugh is speaking from Penrith Library about his latest book "What Makes Us Tick", which deals with happiness in the modern world.

26.title: Episode #2.26
26.plot: On this week's program, we meet Sonia Falero at her event "Beautiful Thing". She discusses her career with journalist Elisabeth Wynhausen at the Riverside Theatre, Parramatta.

27.title: Episode #2.27
27.plot: In a touching act of bravery, Palestinian doctor Izzeldin Abuelaish speaks about the death of his family in Gaza. The speaking event, which is supported by the University of Western Sydney, seeks to move beyond hate and instead discover hope.

28.title: Episode #2.28
28.plot: This double episode promises to educate and entertain. Funnyman Tim Ross talks about his journey to becoming a successful radio personality and now author. And we revisit the Bankstown Youth Development Service (BYD) to see what Sydney Writers' Festival idea they had install for us this year.

29.title: Episode #2.29
29.plot: Over the coming eleven weeks, we will be bringing you the rural Sydney Writers' Festival events that were held in the Carrington Hotel in Katoomba. We kick off with the larger than life Thomas Keneally.

30.title: Episode #2.30
30.plot: In this episode we discuss the journey authors must travel when their stories deal with real life events from the past. "Fiction in History" is the today's event and to discuss the topic we have 3 very talented women: Jesse Blackadder, Judy Johnson and Carol Major.

31.title: Episode #2.31
31.plot: On this week's program we hear from some fresh voices from this year's Commonwealth Writer's Prize: Cynthia Jele, Craig Cliff and Katrina Best. Event Chair David Brooks speaks to these 3 diverse and exciting talents about their work and influences.

32.title: Episode #2.32
32.plot: Over the coming hour the often controversial, occasionally offensive and always entertaining A.A. Gills speaks to Jill Kitson. If you find yourself intrigued, then stay tuned.

33.title: Episode #2.33
33.plot: "Poetry Unbound" is returning to this year's Sydney Writers' Festival line-up by popular demand. Local and regional poets discuss and read from their work. Sounds like a charming way to spend the next hour.

34.title: Episode #2.34
34.plot: One of the most impressive traits of the Sydney Writer's Festival program is that it deals with real and current issues around the world. These issues aren't always pleasant to hear about, but in the hopes of one day building the world into a better place, it is important we listen. Palestinian doctor Izzeldin Abuelaish has dedicated his life to peace in the conflict between Israel and Palestine, despite losing his 3 daughters to the conflict in 2009. Today he tells his story.

35.title: Episode #2.35
35.plot: We are at the Carrington Hotel in Katoomba for a special event from the 2011 Sydney Writer's Festival. In this program author Fiona McGregor discusses what happens when a person's sense of self and place changes.

36.title: Episode #2.36
36.plot: This week Shelf Life meets Aminatta Forna. Over the next hour she talks to Geordie Williamson about "The Memory of Love", a story of friendship, war and obsessive love.

37.title: Episode #2.37
37.plot: You might remember last year we visited the Varuna Writers retreat in the Blue Mountains. Here's another chance to hear about Varuna's figurehead, the award winning Australian author, Eleanor Dark. And with this year being the 20th anniversary of the writers' hide away, the timing couldn't be any better.

38.title: Episode #2.38
38.plot: This week the Festival organisers have decided to include a subject close to everyone's heart. Food, and more specifically what food writers John Newton, Pauline Nguyen, Joanna Savill and Tristan Bancks think about the changing role of food in our society. Stay with us for a lively discussion, which is sure to whet your appetite.

39.title: Episode #2.39
39.plot: To end our Sydney Writers' Festival Series we have an episode for children, or anyone who has children in their life. We take extracts from a fun filled day of events at the Carrington Hotel. This episode features Australia's top children authors: Steven Herrick, Catherine Jinks and Morris Gleitzman.

40.title: Episode #2.40
40.plot: A Shelf Life special: "After Words": Former Prime Minister Paul Keating is in conversation with Kerry O'Brien at the City Recital Hall. They discuss leadership, the role of the monarchy in modern day Australia, the current state of the Labor party and American politics. The talk is based around Mr. Keating's latest book, "After Words", a collection of his post prime-ministerial speeches.

1.title: Episode #3.1
1.plot: In this first episode of the third series, we meet first time published author Felicity Castagna, attend the Sydney Writers' Festival launches and take a sneak peak at the 2012 program. We also introduce our new segment Celebrity Bookshelf, this week media commentator Jane Caro takes us through her home and talks about books that are special to her. In our Bookmark segment, we review "Death at Pemberly" by P.D. James and Jill Dawson's book "Lucky Bunny".

2.title: Episode #3.2
2.plot: This week we visit the home of television veteran Lex Marinos, talk about the future of publishing in the digital world at the E-Exchange conference and take a trip to Corridor café in Newtown and check out the Australian Poetry Café Poet in Residence scheme. We review "A Point of View" by Clive James and Christopher Hitchens' last book "Arguably".

3.title: Episode #3.3
3.plot: In this episode, we meet writer Tony Cavanaugh and visit a Sydney Secondary school to see how teachers are getting students excited about literature. We also attend the Sydney launch for the National Year of Reading and speak to many of the initiative's supporters. We review Peter Corris's book "Mad Dog" and "The Freudian Slip" by Marion Von Adlerstein.

4.title: Episode #3.4
4.plot: This week we talk to UWS historian Associate Professor Andrew Moore about his book "Mr Big of Bankstown". We have the pleasure of meeting Professor Peter Shergold, former senior public servant and current Chancellor at the University of Western Sydney. We visit a RPH branch in Sydney who demonstrates how they improve the lives of millions of Australians with print disabilities through radio broadcast. In our Bookmark segment, we review "Romulus" by Raimond Gaita and Krissy Keen's "Triptych".

5.title: Episode #3.5
5.plot: In Shelf Life this week, we talk to poet and musician Kate Fagan about what she likes to read for leisure and we meet the organiser of the Sydney Jewish Writers' Festival to find out what the event has in store for us this year. We also visit the Behind The Lines Exhibition in Parramatta to see who and what were featured in the best political cartoons of 2011. We review two children's books this week: "Plant a Kiss" by Amy Krouse and "Pirate Pat" by Mairi Mackinnon.

6.title: Episode #3.6
6.plot: This week we talk to not one but two charismatic authors. We chat with Australian writer Christopher Kremmer about his career so far and also introduce you to Irish born Matthew McGuire about his first fiction novel "Dark Dawn". We travel to the Inner West of Sydney for the Penguin Plays Rough evening, and find out how this event has grown. We review "The Apothecary" by Maile Meloy and "The Coming of The Whirlpool" by Andrew McGahan.

7.title: Episode #3.7
7.plot: This week, we visit the UWS Bankstown campus and call in on a magical poetry club that happens once a month. Then we introduce you to celebrity Awra El Masri who speaks about her new memoir/recipe book "Tea With Awra". We're not finished yet, we interview 2012 NSW National Year of Reading Collection winner John Hughes about his collection of autobiographical essays. We review Marina Lewycka's "Various Pets Alive and Dead" and "Goon Squad" by Jennifer Egan.

8.title: Episode #3.8
8.plot: We meet American author Jonathan Englert and discuss his new publishing publicity vehicle WBook. Fashion Writer Glynis Trail-Nash lets us into her home to see what lives on her bookshelf and we speak to University of Western Sydney Associate Professor Hart Cohen about the university's acquisition of the rare manuscript "Songs of Central Australia'. We review Chris Womersley's "Bereft" and Caitlin Moran's "How to be a Woman".

9.title: Episode #3.9
9.plot: This week we visit Indigenous Artist and Fashion Designer Robyn Caughlan about the release of her co-written autobiography and visit the home of Australian broadcaster Ian Rogerson. Then we attend the launch of "3 Novelettes", a collection of short stories written by 3 inspiring young teens. We review Jeanette Winterson's "Why be Happy when you could be Normal" and "Beauty's Sister" by James Bradley.

10.title: Episode #3.10
10.plot: This week we speak with UWS academic Maria Angel about the emerging world of online literature and digital cultures. We visit the home of gossip columnist Ros Reine and once again discover the reading habits of an Australian celebrity. We also attend the launch of Melbourne cartoonist Pat Grant's latest graphic novel. We review Siri Hudsvedt's "What I Loved" and "Revolutionary Road" by Richard Yates.

11.title: Episode #3.11
11.plot: It's that time of the year and we are once again bringing you a variety of the talent on offer at the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival. This week we talk to Russian author and journalist Masha Gesson about her book "The Man Without a Face: The Unlikely Rise of Vladimir Putin".

12.title: Episode #3.12
12.plot: We meet former theatrical agent to the stars and co-author of "Growing Old Outrageously", Hilary Linstead, at the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival.

13.title: Episode #3.13
13.plot: Kate Fagan chairs "Beautiful Brogue" at the Carrington Hotel. Irish novelist Sebastian Barry speaks about his latest work; "On Canaan's Side" is a rich historical novel about Lilly Bere, forced by events in Ireland to flee to America.

14.title: Episode #3.14
14.plot: In this week's interview from the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet writer and comedian Catherine Deveny, who took some time to tell us about her work.

15.title: Episode #3.15
15.plot: This week at the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival, we talk to editor, academic and author David Brooks about his enormous body of work.

16.title: Episode #3.16
16.plot: We meet Finnish novelist Rikka Pulkkinen. She enlightens us about the themes of her latest book.

17.title: Episode #3.17
17.plot: In this week's feature episode from the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival, Shelf Life talks to Icelandic Poet and author Sjon about his vast career to date.

18.title: Episode #3.18
18.plot: We talk to former MP Andrew Tink, whose new political biography "Lord Sydney" is a stunning way to travel back in Australian History.

19.title: Episode #3.19
19.plot: In this week's episode from the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet TV journalist and environmental activist Indira Naidoo. She chats about her book "The Edible Balcony" and inspires us to be more sustainable with food in urban living.

20.title: Episode #3.20
20.plot: In our final author interview from the 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival, we meet Chad Harbach, a New York editor and writer who dazzled the world with his debut "The Art of Fielding".

21.title: Episode #3.21
21.plot: This week we kick off our coverage from the Sydney Writers' Festival Suburban Events. In an event supported by the University of Western Sydney, journalist and author Peter Fitzsimons discusses the saga of Sir Douglas Mawson and his men in his new book "Mawson" at the Penrith Library.

22.title: Episode #3.22
22.plot: The Bankstown Arts Centre hosts "MOVING PEOPLE", the touching and entertaining portrayal of The Westside Writers' Group celebrating the people who come and go from Western Sydney. The University of Western Sydney supports this event.

23.title: Episode #3.23
23.plot: Kate Fagan chairs "BEAUTIFUL BROGUE" at the Carrington Hotel. Irish novelist Sebastian Barry speaks about his latest work, "On Canaan's Side". It is a rich historical novel about Lilly Bere, forced by events in Ireland to flee to America.

24.title: Episode #3.24
24.plot: The Riverside Theatre at Parramatta comes to life with this University of Western Sydney supported event. During "The Rumble", young poets representing Liverpool, Blacktown and Parramatta go head to head in this lively poetry slam competition.

25.title: Episode #3.25
25.plot: As society becomes polarised around issues of terrorism and asylum seekers, how can writers help to build empathy and understanding for our common human condition? Chris McCourt and Ghassan Nakhoul discuss their different approaches in the Blue Mountains event called "Building Empathy in an Age of Terrorism and Asylum Seeking".

26.title: Episode #3.26
26.plot: At another event supported by the University of Western Sydney at the Riverside Theatre in Parramatta, learn of the extraordinary ethical dilemmas faced by former CIA interrogator and author of "The Interrogator", Glen Carle. "No More Nuremberg Defence" is a must see for anyone interested in seeing behind the walls of the CIA.

27.title: Episode #3.27
27.plot: Jesmyn Ward talks to Geordie Williamson at the Carrington Hotel about her heartbreaking novel, "Salvage the Bones". This book, inspired by her own family's experience during Hurricane Katrina, won the 2011 national Book Award for Fiction.

28.title: Episode #3.28
28.plot: In our final 2012 Sydney Writers' Festival event, Charlotte Wood, author of "Animal People" and Carrie Tiffany, author of "Mateship with Birds", talk to Tegan Bennett Daylight about their new books. For animal lovers "The Human Ark" discussion should not be missed.

imdb.plot outline: Shelf Life is a half hour program produced by the University of Western Sydney that delves into the thoughts of both local and visiting authors to showcase what's on offer for Australians who are keen to put their bookmark to use. The television show explores what everyday people are reading and uncovers new writers and novels of interest to both avid readers and bookshelf browsers. Presented by Dr Milissa Deitz and Dr Rachel Morley from the UWS School of Humanities and Communication Arts, Shelf Life also features a host of guests including academics, authors & entertainers.
imdb.title: Shelf Life
plot: _Shelf Life_ (qv) is a half hour program produced by the University of Western Sydney that delves into the thoughts of both local and visiting authors to showcase what's on offer for Australians who are keen to put their bookmark to use. The television show explores what everyday people are reading and uncovers new writers and novels of interest to both avid readers and bookshelf browsers. Presented by Dr Milissa Deitz and Dr Rachel Morley from the UWS School of Humanities and Communication Arts, _Shelf Life_ (qv) also features a host of guests including academics, authors & entertainers.
